intro: Corydalis diphylla subsp. occidentalis, commonly known as western twinflower, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its delicate, spurred flowers that range in color from pink to purple. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and rocky slopes. It has two pairs of opposite leaves and produces small, capsule-like fruits containing several seeds. Its botanical features make it an attractive and ecologically important species in its native habitat.
